content.raw:
Interesting, from the conversation on the FIRST models, I had understood that fixed joints were significantly less stable than having solid parts. But I hadn't thought of how they compare to the old approach of using revolute joints with equal low and high limits (which I thought was also very unstable because it's constantly pressing against the joint limits).

The change to use fixed joints in the gripper was not important for this PR, so I can make a PR reverting it until we have data on what would be the best approach.
content.html:
Interesting, from the conversation on the FIRST models, I had understood that fixed joints were significantly less stable than having solid parts. But I hadn't thought of how they compare to the old approach of using revolute joints with equal low and high limits (which I thought was also very unstable because it's constantly pressing against the joint limits).

The change to use fixed joints in the gripper was not important for this PR, so I can make a PR reverting it until we have data on what would be the best approach.

content.raw: @chapulina The new fixed joint approach is less stable numerically. I don't have an exact quantifier for the effects, but I did observe this trend when we were working on the FIRST models. This will very likely break some existing models out there in the world, but we should start by having a test to measure the exact effects of this change.
content.html: @chapulina The new fixed joint approach is less stable numerically. I don't have an exact quantifier for the effects, but I did observe this trend when we were working on the FIRST models. This will very likely break some existing models out there in the world, but we should start by having a test to measure the exact effects of this change.

content.raw:
Both failures seem to be because of features missing in dart:

* `INTEGRATION_nested_model`: dart doesn't support nested models

* `INTEGRATION_joint_test` fails with these messages:

~~~
223: [ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/JointTest.DynamicJointVisualization/3
223: [Dbg] [joint_test.hh:64] Params: (0x45dbc9 pointing to "dart", 0x460380 pointing to "")
223: [Msg] Waiting for master.
223: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
223: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.35
223: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:200] ServerFixture load in 0.7 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
223: [Wrn] [Model.cc:1435] Model [box1] already has a joint named [dynamic_joint_unique], skipping creating joint.
223: [Err] [DARTJoint.cc:178] DART does not support joint dettaching.
223: [Wrn] [Model.cc:1468] Joint [this_joint_doees_not_exist] does not exist in model [box1], not removed.
223: 
223: 
 45/140 Test #223: INTEGRATION_joint_test ................................***Exception: SegFault147.20 sec
~~~

So it might be due to detaching not being supported.
content.html:
Both failures seem to be because of features missing in dart:

  • INTEGRATION_nested_model: dart doesn't support nested models

  • INTEGRATION_joint_test fails with these messages:

223: [ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/JointTest.DynamicJointVisualization/3
223: [Dbg] [joint_test.hh:64] Params: (0x45dbc9 pointing to "dart", 0x460380 pointing to "")
223: [Msg] Waiting for master.
223: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
223: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.2.35
223: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:200] ServerFixture load in 0.7 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
223: [Wrn] [Model.cc:1435] Model [box1] already has a joint named [dynamic_joint_unique], skipping creating joint.
223: [Err] [DARTJoint.cc:178] DART does not support joint dettaching.
223: [Wrn] [Model.cc:1468] Joint [this_joint_doees_not_exist] does not exist in model [box1], not removed.
223: 
223: 
 45/140 Test #223: INTEGRATION_joint_test ................................***Exception: SegFault147.20 sec

So it might be due to detaching not being supported.

update.description:
Breaking pull request #2107 into smaller bits.

This makes sure the call for `physics::remove_worlds()` cleans up the world and physics engine shared pointers and properly terminates the transport topics related to that world.

* There are several calls to `reset` shared pointers in destructors which are probably not necessary, but I think there's no harm to leave them there while these issues are being fixed as a reminder of what needs to be properly cleaned up. If someone is bothered by them I can remove them.

* This branch was making the `INTEGRATION_gripper` test fail occasionally. It looks like some raw pointers have bad values by the time they're accessed on `ODEJoint::Detach`. I couldn't find the source of the problem and can't tell if it is within ODE or in the way we're using it. I was able to work around it checking if some pointers are valid before calling `dJointAttach`.

* In the process of debugging the gripper test, I also changed its implementation to use the new fixed joints instead of the old way of doing fixed joints.

[trusty no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/269/) is :large_blue_circle:
update.title: Remove blank world

content.raw: Nevermind, it's hard for me to reproduce this on my machine so it would take time to debug. I was looking into how [`dBodyDestroy`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/86b8dcf6a5b1dbd02d8ae1c6eacc630cf617787e/deps/opende/src/ode.cpp?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ode.cpp-310), which deletes the ODE pointer, is called both on [`ODELink::~ODELink`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/86b8dcf6a5b1dbd02d8ae1c6eacc630cf617787e/gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODELink.cc-44) and [`ODELink::Fini`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/86b8dcf6a5b1dbd02d8ae1c6eacc630cf617787e/gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ODELink.cc-179). But they don't seem to be playing a role here, so I'll leave that fix for later tests.
content.html: Nevermind, it's hard for me to reproduce this on my machine so it would take time to debug. I was looking into how dBodyDestroy, which deletes the ODE pointer, is called both on ODELink::~ODELink and ODELink::Fini. But they don't seem to be playing a role here, so I'll leave that fix for later tests.

content.raw: I have an idea why this is happening, looking into it now.
content.html: I have an idea why this is happening, looking into it now.

update.description:
Breaking pull request #2107 into smaller bits.

This makes sure the call for `physics::remove_worlds()` cleans up the world and physics engine shared pointers and properly terminates the transport topics related to that world.

* There are several calls to `reset` shared pointers in destructors which are probably not necessary, but I think there's no harm to leave them there while these issues are being fixed as a reminder of what needs to be properly cleaned up. If someone is bothered by them I can remove them.

* This branch was making the `INTEGRATION_gripper` test fail occasionally. It looks like some raw pointers have bad values by the time they're accessed on `ODEJoint::Detach`. I couldn't find the source of the problem and can't tell if it is within ODE or in the way we're using it. I was able to work around it checking if some pointers are valid before calling `dJointAttach`.

* In the process of debugging the gripper test, I also changed its implementation to use the new fixed joints instead of the old way of doing fixed joints.

[trusty no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/269/) is :large_blue_circle:
